Fatboy: Though monetary stimulus alone isn't sufficient to restore our economy to full employment, it provides some support to aggregated demand, so it is better than nothing. Professor Krugman and the Neo-Keynesian cohort have maintained from the beginning of our instant crisis and in accord with Keynesian theory that a large and robust fiscal stimulus is needed along with a robust monetary stimulus to right our economy.

However, because of our dysfunctional politics and pernicious austerity economics, the Congress has never implemented an adequate fiscal stimulus, nor is it likely to do so. That means there is no adequate stimulation of demand, so that business can earn a sufficient risk-adjusted return on borrowed money, even at these very low rates.

But monetary policy of holding short-term rates at effectively zero does some good, because it prevents aggregate demand from falling below its current meager levels. It does that in two ways: First, it relieves debt by permitting refinancing for both consumers and businesses at low rates and also keeps variable finance charges lower, and (2) it permits financing of operations and new consumption at very low rates, without which aggregate demand would be even lower, as we've seen in the Eurozone and EU.

And don't worry that the assets markets will develop dangerous bubbles, for at the instant rates of unemployment, low prices of real assets and goods, and our recent experience with bubbles, that is quite unlikely.

Most guns have a relatively short shelf life if not used and maintained.  The steel us especially receptive to corrosion, so in places that are even seasonally humid, (say Nevada), the metal decays if not kept dry and oiled.  Once the tolerances in the action are compromised the gun becomes much less effective.  My guess is that in a decade more than half of the 300 M arms would be largely dysfunctional.

I see people who support the War on Drugs as a different category of gun lover. They love the idea of using armed police to fight drugs. The increasing militarization of the police in the name of reducing substance abuse is another kind of gun control debate we need to be having in this country. I know fellow Democrats who are very anti-gun as long as the gun in question is owned by a private citizen of the Republican persuasion. But these same Democratic friends of mine think nothing of the government sending hordes of federal agents armed with assault rifles to take down a marijuana grow. The War on Drugs is one more side to the story of America as a gun-loving nation. It's no accident that the former head of the Bush DEA, Asa Hutchinson, who has sent more than his share of assault-rifle-toting agents into marijuana fields, is currently serving as the NRA's point man when it comes to fighting gun control.

In reply to DD's comment, "nonviolent drug offender" who "should be treated with treatment".... Forget the "if an addict". Good luck distinguishing between an addict and one who's not.

That's the problem. People can use drugs responsibly, even if most people who use those drugs do not.

We don't tell people who have a glass of wine every night with their dinner that they need treatment.

Mandated treatment is a thoughtless punishment that is apparently popular to say, even though no real thought goes into its meaning and consequences. It sounds good.

It's also pointless for most people. Neither jail nor treatment is the answer for some people.

We don't need a good reason for decriminalizing drugs, we need a good reason for criminalizing them in the first place.
